proposals.reasoning: Putting myself (Eve) on the team guarantees at least one player I know is good, and pairing with Alice tests the player most broadly trusted so far without giving the consensus Alice–Bob duo an easy, auto-cleared start. If this mission passes with Alice–Eve, it builds strong trust in both of us; if it fails, it sharply narrows suspicion onto a small set instead of letting two widely trusted players potentially coordinate a hidden fail.

votes.comment: Team is likely low-risk for Mission 1 and avoids the heavily pushed Alice–Bob duo, giving us information without immediately auto-clearing a pair.
Eve is the least tested and most contested pick so far; I’d rather start with the broadly trusted Alice–Bob pair than risk giving an unknown a potential early fail opportunity.

I’m uneasy with auto-trusting the leader’s self-inclusion and sidelining Bob after he was in the most-discussed pair; I’d rather see a team that better reflects the early consensus or includes more clearly debated options first.
As evil, I want at least one of myself or Charlie on the mission to allow a possible sabotage; this team has neither of us.
I know I’m good, and this tests the widely trusted Alice without giving the Alice–Bob pair an easy auto-clear start.

proposals.reasoning: This pairing has the broadest support and is the lowest-friction way to get an early read: both players have been active and transparent in discussion, making it easier for everyone to evaluate their actions and votes afterward. Starting with a relatively consensus, low-drama team for Mission 1 lets us gather information without immediately sidelining anyone based on very thin early-game reads.

votes.comment: Consensus low-drama pair for Mission 1; we need early info and there’s no strong reason to suspect this combo yet.
I know I’m good, and Alice–Bob has broad support with no strong red flags yet. Getting an early mission with at least one confirmed-good-from-my-perspective is valuable for information.
I’ve already argued Alice–Bob is the safest low-drama first mission; rejecting it now would be inconsistent and suspicious, so I’ll back the consensus team.
Both proposed members are good from my perspective, so this would give good a clean early success and too much trust-building.
Early mission with a broadly supported, talkative pair is fine for information; odds both are evil are low and we learn a lot from the result and later patterns.

discussion.content: For a 2-person first mission, I’d lean toward lower-risk picks like Bob and Eve so we can get some information without giving too much control to anyone who’s been quiet or vague so far. It’s early, but that combo feels like a reasonable starting point.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I’m not sold on Eve yet just because we have almost no info. I’d rather hear a bit more from everyone and would also consider pairs like Alice–Bob or Alice–Charlie before we lock it in.

I’m inclined to agree that Alice–Bob is the safest low-drama pair for the first mission, since they’re both being pretty transparent so far. I’d rather keep Eve off this one until we’ve heard a bit more from her and seen how people react to an initial clean or failed mission.

I’m okay with an Alice–Bob first mission since they’ve both been pretty clear so far, but I’d also like to hear a bit more from Eve before we leave her off entirely and accidentally start hard-clearing the wrong people.

If we auto-default to Alice–Bob, we risk giving two evils a very easy, trusted start, so I’d prefer a split like Alice–Eve or Bob–Eve to get information on at least one person who isn’t already being soft-cleared by everyone.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and me (Bob) succeeded with no fails, so keeping that core is currently our best baseline of apparent reliability while still acknowledging one of us could theoretically be a hidden evil who chose to pass. For Mission 2, I want to maximize information gain rather than just follow the loudest preference, so I’m adding Charlie as the new third member. Charlie volunteered to be the info-gathering addition and is reasonably active in discussion, which means if this mission fails we’ll have clearer behavioral and voting data to analyze compared to adding a quieter or more consensus-driven player. This team preserves a proven pair and tests a new player who can be meaningfully read from both the mission result and their subsequent reactions.

votes.comment: I still prefer keeping the Alice–Bob core but adding Eve for a cleaner info read; putting Charlie on now muddies things if it fails and goes against the earlier emerging preference for testing Eve first.
I trust the Alice+Bob core from the clean first mission and adding Charlie gives good info without introducing multiple unknowns at once.
I’m on the team and it keeps the trusted Alice–Bob core intact, so I want this to go through to keep suspicion low and gain info.
My evil teammate is on the team, and a potential fail here helps shift suspicion onto that core early.
Keeping the proven Alice+Bob core and testing Charlie gives useful info early without any strong reason yet to distrust this lineup.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’m inclined to keep Bob on and add someone who wasn’t involved yet—Eve feels like a reasonable pick so we can test a new player without overhauling what’s already worked.
I’m okay staying on the team since mission 1 was clean, but I’d rather add someone we can pressure a bit more than Eve—maybe Charlie—so we’re not just blindly accepting the first new name.

I’m fine being the new addition if we want more info, but I agree the safest core right now is still Alice + Bob, and then we just need to decide which of Eve, Diana, or me gives us the best read going forward.

I still like keeping the Alice + Bob core since mission 1 was clean, and if we’re just adding one new person for info, I slightly prefer Eve over Charlie so we’re not immediately stacking the most vocal players on the same team and muddying the read if it fails.
I’m fine sticking with the Alice + Bob core and adding me this round, but if we do that we should all agree that a fail there puts heavy suspicion on that core rather than just blaming the new add.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve already run Alice + Bob twice, which keeps us blind about everyone else. At 2–0, I don’t want to hand the same unchanged pair a third mission when, if there is a slow-playing evil between them, this is exactly when they’d cash it in. Keeping Alice maintains some continuity with the successful missions, but swapping Bob for me introduces new information and slightly diversifies the risk while not overhauling the team structure completely.

votes.comment: At 2–0 we should minimize risk; putting an untested player like Charlie on a tiny 2-person mission feels unnecessary when we have a fully clean 2-person combo available.
Alice+Bob is the only pair proven over multiple missions; introducing untested Charlie adds unnecessary risk when we only need one more success.
Consistent with my earlier point about varying from the Alice+Bob core to gain new information while keeping Alice for continuity.
This still breaks up the repeated Alice+Bob core and gives us new information while keeping at least one proven member, which feels safer than handing the same unchanged pair a third mission.
We’re 2–0 up and Alice+Bob has twice proven clean; swapping in Charlie adds unnecessary risk when we only need one more success.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve only ever seen the Alice + Bob core, which means if one of them is evil and slow-playing, they can end the game with a single fail here. Keeping Alice maintains continuity with the clean missions so far, but swapping Bob out for me both reduces the risk of reusing the identical pair a third time and gives the table new information about another player on a small, high-signal mission.

votes.comment: Diana on the team introduces unnecessary risk when we’re one mission from winning; safer to stick with pairs that already look clean.
Alice and I are the only fully proven pair so far; introducing Diana adds more risk than reusing the already twice-clean Alice+Bob combo when we’re up 2–0.
We need to stop auto-locking Alice+Bob; this keeps Alice for continuity but adds a new partner, which gives more information and avoids the risk of blindly reusing the same pair a third time.
I’m on the team, so this gives evil a direct chance to sabotage and prevents good from winning 3–0 uncontested.
Alice and Bob are the most proven pair with two clean missions; swapping Bob for Diana adds unnecessary risk when we only need one more success.

proposals.reasoning: Both previous missions that included Alice and Bob (including the smaller 2-person team on Mission 1) succeeded with 0 FAIL cards, giving us the strongest empirical evidence that this pair is safe. With the score already 2–0 in favor of Good and only a 2-person team required, reusing the proven Alice+Bob combination minimizes new risk on a potential game-winning mission. If this team were to fail, we’d immediately know that at least one of them is evil, greatly clarifying the endgame, but if it succeeds we win outright. This balance of high success likelihood plus strong informational value makes Alice and Bob the optimal choice.

votes.comment: We’re up 2–0 and this exact pair has already passed a 2-person mission cleanly; reusing the only fully tested combo is the lowest-risk way to try to win here.
Both previous missions with Alice+Bob, including a 2-person team, succeeded with 0 fails; with a 2–0 lead this is the safest low-variance, potentially game-winning choice.

I’m still uncomfortable giving the exact same core a third straight mission when we’ve learned nothing about the rest of the table—if one of them is slow-playing evil, this is the game-ending risk with no new info gained, so I’d rather see at least one new person swapped in.
As evil, I don’t want to send an all-good pair that’s already passed twice on a potential game-winning mission for Good.

Alice+Bob have twice passed with 0 fails, including as a 2-person team, and at 2–0 this is the highest-percent, game-winning shot; if it somehow fails, we at least pinpoint evil to within those two for the endgame.

discussion.content: Given we only need two people, I’d stick with the mission 1 pair of me and Bob—those are the only two who’ve been on a smaller team that already passed cleanly.

Given we’re already up 2–0, I’d rather not introduce new risk—sticking with the proven Alice + Bob pair for this 2-person mission seems safest. If either of us were evil, they’ve passed twice already, so at least this combo is clearly motivated to keep missions clean.

I get the logic of reusing Alice + Bob, but the fact that we’ve only ever seen that core together means we’ve learned basically nothing about anyone else—I'd rather see a slight variation like Alice + me so we at least start getting some new information instead of blindly locking in the same pair.

I’m a little uneasy about giving the exact same core a third shot—if one of Alice/Bob is evil just slow-playing, they only need this one fail to win, so I’d rather keep Alice for consistency but pair her with someone new like me to at least reduce that risk and get more info.

Given we’re already 2–0 up and both missions with Alice + Bob were clean, I’m inclined to keep that pair for this small team—if it somehow fails, we at least clearly narrow evil down to one of them going into the last missions.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Alice as Merlin. From the start she kept gently but consistently anchoring around the correct good core (her + Bob), always sounding “reason-based” instead of paranoid, and never seriously pushed to include either of us despite multiple opportunities to shake things up. Bob feels more like a cautious good who’s reacting to table vibes, whereas Alice keeps proactively steering composition in a way that’s exactly right if she already knows who’s safe.

I’m with you that Alice is the best Merlin hit: from mission 1 onward she calmly framed “safe” logic that always happened to keep the real good core (her + Bob) intact, and she never seriously entertained putting both of us in even when that would’ve been a very normal “info-gathering” suggestion from a true blind good. Her tone is that classic soft-directing style—she proposes structures, not wild reads, and every structure just happens to preserve exactly the right people while sounding like generic risk management.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From mission 1 onward, Alice consistently advocated for the Alice–Bob core and framed it as the ‘safe, low-risk’ option, which always protected the actual good core without ever meaningfully pushing to include both evils, even when that would have been a standard info-gathering move for a blind good player. Her tone stayed calm and structurally focused—proposing lineups that just happened to be correct rather than actively hunting—which fits Merlin quietly steering rather than a normal good guessing in the dark.
